ery fast browser with a lot of features, built-in email client, newsreader, feed reader. Strict web standards compliance means scripts on some sites written for IE or Firefox won't always work. Google sites often have problems with this.

The best multi-purpose web browser available. A bit memory hungry, but comparable to other modern browsers. Take it easy with the addons as installing and uninstalling many of them tends to degrade the Firefox installation over time.
The most feature rich and well thought out video player for Linux. So many of MPlayer's hidden switches and settings are available in an extremely well laid out way.
Plays everything you throw at it and plays it well. The GUI is horrible. I recommend SMPlayer as a front end.

The plugin for viewing videos embedded in web pages is nice. Does Youtube without Flash. But has very few settings you can tweak. If your video doesn't play well with the default settings, you're pretty much stuck.
Plays just about every video type. Better GUI than default MPlayer but a little heavier on system resources as well.
Excellent for most CDDVD burning tasks. Lacks a few features K3B has but most people won't notice.
Has just about every feature you could imagine in a well laid out GUI.
By far the best way to manage and play a large music collection. If you only play mp3's occasionally, Amarok is probably overkill. Many useful scripts can be used to extend functionality.
A clone of the original Winamp Music Player for Windows. Very good for playing a few mp3's quickly. Not so good for managing a large music collection.
Very fast and stable file manager. Has tabs and media support in sidebar. Lacks support for easy extension through scripts like Thunar and Nautilus. It really needs Trash Can support.
Excellent file manager with full media and Trash features. Customizable user actions can be created easily. A bit sluggish compared to other GTK file managers. Also supports tabbed file browsing.

Faster than Nautilus but still has Media and Trash features as well as customizable user actions. Has an annoying bug where certain file types pop up behind the Thunar window rather than in front when launched.
Good text editor with some useful plugins. A bit sluggish for just viewing text files.
Views text files instantly. Limited feature and plugin support.
Same feature set as Leafpad but a little slower.
Good simple terminal text editor. Not as feature packed as vim, but then again what is?
You can do just about anything with this editor but the price is a steeper learning curve.
Has everything the home user is likely to need in a word processor. Much smaller download and more responsive than Openoffice.
Part of the fully integrated Openoffice suite. More suited to office users than home users. A LOT of features leave it a little sluggish and slow to open.
Allows you to control what daemons and services start when you boot your computer. For example, don't use Bluetooth devices? Uncheck the box and turn it off.
Easy to read text based process manager. Very useful to run in a virtual terminal to identify and kill programs that may be freezing your X session.
Lets you install another operating system inside of the one you're currently running. Good for testing purposes.
A cool idea, but development hangs well behind the actual WINE project so things are often broken.
The best way to control every last bit of what is installed on your system. A very small learning curve for new users but it is worth it.

A very useful tool for scouting out places you might want to go. Plugins identify nearby parks, restaurants, entertainment and transportation services. It's also fun to just poke around places that look interesting.
The plugins make it the best way to send instant messages and keep track of buddies. Multimedia features are lacking.
Good performance and great feature set. Good if you need to seed and manage many torrents.

Lets you access buddies on AIM, Yahoo, MSN, Google, Facebook, Myspace, ICQ, IRC and many others. Plugins extend functionality even further. Supports custom smiley themes. VoIP and video chat performance is so-so.
Best GUI IRC client for Linux. Highly configurable. Supports python, perl, and tcl scripts out of the box.
Fast and feature-rich BitTorrent client. Can be run as a daemon without the GUI. Supports plugins. Highly configurable.
My favorite text viewer. Very fast and simple. Doesn't have IDE features built in so if you want to code with it you'll have to do all the heavy lifting yourself.

Heaviest audio player on Linux but also most featureful. Best for managing large collections if you set up a SQL database. Built in script manager adds tons of features. Can't browse itunes shares. Never had much luck with it recognizing mp3 players.

The best front end for the best video player on PC's. Will play anything you can throw at it. The configuration options are deep, but well laid out and self explanatory. The most important settings can all be changed directly from the player window.

Great video player. Most of the player's myriad options aren't available from the GUI. SMPlayer uses the same back end but provides a much better interface in my opinion.

Good WYSIWYG editor for making DVD menus. Also lets you automatically create DVD slideshows out of picture files. Could really use a grid to line up rows of menu buttons. Currently you can only automatically align one row at a time.
Best burning app on any platform. Even blows Nero out of the water. Lots of features without being bloated and does not often give errors in burning.
Very good burner. Power users will probably want K3b, but this is good enough for ~90% of uses. Integrates well with Nautilus which is a big plus for GNOME users.

Lightning fast PDF viewer. Not as featureful as Evince or the offical Adobe Reader. Perfect for doing what most people want, which is to look at PDF's quickly.
Lightweight word processor. More responsive than Openoffice, but occasionally hiccups on opening Word documents.
Fast image viewer, supports zoom and image rotation. No editing features.

Linux and Mac versions of Skype haven't been updated in ages. still works (barely), but you'll want to check out QuteCom, which is a free replacement.
Kopete is much more feature-rich than any other IM client for linux. VideoAudio chat has been included for ages, and is quite stable. supports almost every IM protocol ever created.

what it does, it does well. new features take ages to arrive, and the developers are known as being the biggest jerks in the open source community. Kopete supports more protocols. use if you have to, but there are better options.

absolute garbage, when compared to Thunderbird and Spicebird. if you have standard settings for imapsmtppop3 (i.e. standard ports), it'll work. otherwise, try a better client. Novell has run this app into the ground since buying it from Ximian.

the best cross-platform email client on the planet. supports everything but MAPI. this is the closest Linux has to an Outlook replacement. if you want IM integration, check out Spicebird. otherwise, give this app a try.
this app has saved my bacon so many times. Originally a windows-only FOSS application, it's finally been ported. highly recommended for power users that dislike the limitations of Nautilus.
DGen is a dinosaur. hasn't been updated in at least 6 years. try GensGS if you want a decent GenesisMegadrive emulator.
98% accurate. for most games, that's good enough. if you want to play Solar Jetman correctly, check out NEStopia.
the most accurate and stable SNES emulator since 1999. Highly recommended.

VBA is incredible. the first GBA emulator to run at a decent speed (not counting no$gba). very accurate emulation. easy to configurerun. best emulator for GameboyAdvance.
the successor to XMame, written by R. Belmont and the former XMame devs. supports over 5,000 arcade games. highly recommended if you're into arcade games.
perfect Atari 2600 emulation. even supports paddles via mousetrackball input. it even plays games that had trouble playing on a real 2600 (He-Man ANDAND The Masters of The Universe).
hasn't been updated since 2002. reasonably good emulation, supports Pete's OpenGL graphics plugins (FFIX at 1920x1080 is amazing). download if you must, otherwise, try pSX.
